qas.question: Who was the first person to connect several Leyden jars in parallel?
Where did Benjamin Franklin believe the charge was stored in Leyden jars?
How many nanofarads did the earliest unit of capacitance equate to?
Why was a gap left at the mouth of Leyden jars?

answers.text: to prevent arcing between the foils

qas.question: Who was the second person to connect several Leyden jars in parallel?
Where did Benjamin Franklin believe the charge was released in Leyden jars?
How many nanofarads did the earliest unit of capacitance subtract?

plausible_answers.text: to prevent arcing between the foils

qas.question: Why was the mouth of Leyden jars closed?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Daniel Gralath<b5_0/><a0_0/> was the first to combine several jars in parallel into a "battery" to increase the charge storage capacity. <a2_0><b7_0>Benjamin Franklin<b7_0/><a2_0/> investigated the Leyden jar and came to the conclusion that the charge was <a1_0><b6_0>stored on the glass<b6_0/><a1_0/>, not in the water as others had assumed. He also adopted the term "battery", (denoting the increasing of power with a row of similar units as in a battery of cannon), subsequently applied to clusters of electrochemical cells. Leyden jars were later made by coating the inside and outside of jars with metal foil, leaving a space at the mouth <a4_0><b9_0>to prevent arcing between the foils<b9_0/><a4_0/>.[citation needed] The earliest unit of capacitance was the jar, equivalent to about <a3_0><b8_0>1.11 nanofarads<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
